standard_metadata.standard_description: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

question.content: The following figure shows a right triangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A right triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 4 units and 11 units. The side face has side lengths of 3 units and 11 units. The diagonal side face has side lengths of 5 units and 11 units. The triangular prism has a height of 3 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the triangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 3 rectangles and 2 right triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 11 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 11 units. The third rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 11 units.  There is a right triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the triangles.  $\greenD{\text{Triangles}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \dfrac12\times \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times3\times4 \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times12 \\\\ &= \greenD6 \end{align}$  There are two triangle faces with an area of $\greenD6$ square units.  So, we add $\greenD6$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each rectangle.  $\blueD{\text{Left rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 3\times11 \\\\ &= \blueD{33} \end{align}$  $\purpleD{\text{Center rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 4\times11 \\\\ &= \purpleD{44} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{\text{Right rectangle}}$:   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 5\times11 \\\\ &= \maroonD{55} \end{align}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the triangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\greenD6+\greenD6+\blueD{33}+\purpleD{44}+\maroonD{55}$

question.content: The following figure shows a right triangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A right triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 4 units and 10 units. The side face has side lengths of 3 units and 10 units. The diagonal side face has side lengths of 5 units and 10 units. The triangular prism has a height of 3 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the triangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 3 rectangles and 2 right triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 10 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 10 units. The third rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 10 units.  There is a right triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding area of the triangles.  $\greenD{\text{Triangles}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \dfrac12\times \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times4\times3 \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times12 \\\\ &= \greenD{6} \end{align}$  There are two triangle faces with an area of $\greenD{6}$ square units.  So, we add $\greenD{6}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each rectangle.  $\blueD{\text{Left rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 3\times10 \\\\ &= \blueD{30} \end{align}$  $\purpleD{\text{Center rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 4\times10 \\\\ &= \purpleD{40} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{\text{Right rectangle}}$:   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 5\times10 \\\\ &= \maroonD{50} \end{align}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the triangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\greenD{6}+\greenD{6}+\blueD{30}+\purpleD{40}+\maroonD{50}$

question.content: The following figure shows a right triangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A right triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 8 units and 20 units. The side face has side lengths of 6 units and 20 units. The diagonal side face has side lengths of 10 units and 20 units. The triangular prism has a height of 6 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the triangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 3 rectangles and 2 right triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 20 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 8 units and a height of 20 units. The third rectangle has a base of 10 units and a height of 20 units.  There is a right triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 8 units and a height of 6 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding area of the triangles.  $\greenD{\text{Triangles}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \dfrac12\times \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times6\times8 \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times48 \\\\ &= \greenD{24} \end{align}$  There are two triangle faces with an area of $\greenD{24}$ square units.  So, we add $\greenD{24}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each rectangle.  $\blueD{\text{Left rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 6\times20 \\\\ &= \blueD{120} \end{align}$  $\purpleD{\text{Center rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 8\times20 \\\\ &= \purpleD{160} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{\text{Right rectangle}}$:   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 10\times20 \\\\ &= \maroonD{200} \end{align}$

Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  $\greenD{24}+\greenD{24}+\blueD{120}+\purpleD{160}+\maroonD{200}$  The following expression represents the surface area of the triangular prism.  $2\cdot\greenD{24}+\blueD{120}+\purpleD{160}+\maroonD{200}$

question.content: The following figure shows a right triangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 8 units and 11 units. The other 2 faces have side lengths of 5 units and 11 units. The triangular prism has a height of 2 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the triangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 3 rectangles and 2 triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 11 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 8 units and a height of 11 units. The third rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 11 units.  There is a triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each triangle has a base of 8 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding area of the triangles.  $\blueD{\text{Triangles}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \dfrac12\times \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times8\times2 \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times16 \\\\ &= \blueD{8} \end{align}$  There are two triangle faces with an area of $\blueD{8}$ square units.  So, we add $\blueD{8}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each rectangle.  $\maroonD{\text{Left rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 5\times11 \\\\ &= \maroonD{55} \end{align}$  $\greenD{\text{Center rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 8\times11 \\\\ &= \greenD{88} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{\text{Right rectangle}}$:   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 5\times11 \\\\ &= \maroonD{55} \end{align}$

Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.    $\blueD{8}+\blueD{8}+\maroonD{55}+\maroonD{55}+\greenD{88}$  The following expression represents the surface area of the triangular prism.  $2\cdot \blueD{8}+2\cdot \maroonD{55}+\greenD{88}$

question.content: The following figure shows a right triangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 6 units and 2 units. The other 2 faces have side lengths of 4 units and 2 units. The triangular prism has a height of 1 unit.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the triangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 3 rectangles and 2 triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the short side.  The first rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 2 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 2 units. The third rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 2 units.  There is a triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each triangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 1 unit.

hints.content: Let's start by finding area of the triangles.  $\blueD{\text{Triangles}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \dfrac12\times \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times6\times1 \\\\  &= \dfrac12 \times6 \\\\ &= \blueD{3} \end{align}$  There are two triangle faces with an area of $\blueD{3}$ square units.  So, we add $\blueD{3}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each rectangle.  $\maroonD{\text{Left rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 4\times2 \\\\ &= \maroonD{8} \end{align}$  $\greenD{\text{Center rectangle}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 6\times2 \\\\ &= \greenD{12} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{\text{Right rectangle}}$:   $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 4\times2 \\\\ &= \maroonD{8} \end{align}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the triangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}+\greenD{12}+\maroonD{8}+\maroonD{8}$

question.content: The following figure shows a right rectangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A rectangular prism. The length is 4 units. The width is 2 units. The height is 1 unit.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the rectangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 6 rectangles.  4 of the rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 1 unit and a height of 4 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 4 units. The third rectangle has a base of 1 unit and a height of 4 units.  The fourth rectangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 4 units. There is a rectangle connected to the top and a rectangle connected to the bottom of the second rectangle, each with a base of 2 units and a height of 1 unit.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the bottom face.  The $\purpleE{\text{bottom rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &=  2\times4 \\\\ &= \purpleE{8} \end{align}$  The top face has the same area as the bottom face. So we add $\purpleE{8}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each other face.  The $\blueE{\text{front rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 4\times1 \\\\ &= \blueE{4} \end{align}$  The back face has the same area as the front face. So we add $\blueE{4}$ twice.  $\maroonE{\text{Leftmost rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 2\times1 \\\\ &= \maroonD{2} \end{align}$  The rightmost face has the same area as the leftmost face.  So, we add $\maroonE{2}$ twice.
Finally, we add the area of all $6$ faces.  We can find the surface area of the rectangular prism with the following expression:  $\purpleE8+\purpleE8+\blueE{4}+\blueE{4}+\maroonE{2}+\maroonE{2}$

The second rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 5 units. The third rectangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 5 units.  The fourth rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 5 units. There is a rectangle connected to the top and a rectangle connected to the bottom of the second rectangle, each with a base of 3 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the bottom face.  The $\purpleE{\text{bottom rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &=  3\times5 \\\\ &= \purpleE{15} \end{align}$  The top face has the same area as the bottom face. So we add $\purpleE{15}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each other face.  The $\blueE{\text{front rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 2\times5 \\\\ &= \blueE{10} \end{align}$  The back face has the same area as the front face. So we add $\blueE{10}$ twice.  $\maroonE{\text{Leftmost rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 2\times3 \\\\ &= \maroonE{6} \end{align}$  The rightmost face has the same area as the leftmost face.  So, we add $\maroonE{6}$ twice.

Finally, we add the area of all $6$ faces.  We can find the surface area of the rectangular prism with the following expression:  $\purpleE{15}+\purpleE{15}+\blueE{10}+\blueE{10}+\maroonE{6}+\maroonE{6}$

The $\purpleE{\text{bottom rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &=  3\times5 \\\\ &= \purpleE{15} \end{align}$  The top face has the same area as the bottom face. The $\maroonE{\text{front rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 6\times3 \\\\ &= \maroonE{18} \end{align}$  The back face has the same area as the front face. So we add $\maroonD{18}$ twice.

Finally, we add the area of all $6$ faces.  $\purpleE{15}+\purpleE{15}+\blueE{30}+\blueE{30}+\maroonE{18}+\maroonE{18}$  The following expression represents the surface area of the rectangular prism.  $2\cdot \purpleE{15}+2 \cdot \blueE{30}+2 \cdot \maroonE{18}$

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the bottom face.  The $\purpleE{\text{bottom rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &=  2\times3 \\\\ &= \purpleE{6} \end{align}$  The top face has the same area as the bottom face. So we add $\purpleE{6}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each blue and red face.  $\blueE{\text{Leftmost rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 2\times5 \\\\ &= \blueE{10} \end{align}$  The rightmost face has the same area as the leftmost face.  So, we add $\blueE{10}$ twice.  The $\maroonE{\text{front rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height}  \\\\  &= 5\times3 \\\\ &= \maroonE{15} \end{align}$  The back face has the same area as the front face. So we add $\maroonD{15}$ twice.

Finally, we add the area of all $6$ faces.  $\purpleE{6}+\purpleE{6}+\blueE{10}+\blueE{10}+\maroonE{15}+\maroonE{15}$  The following expression represents the surface area of the rectangular prism.  $2\cdot \purpleE{6}+2 \cdot \blueE{10}+2 \cdot \maroonE{15}$

question.content: The following figure shows a right rectangular prism.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the prism?**

images.alt: A rectangular prism. The length is 4 units. The width is 8 units. The height is 7 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the rectangular prism.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net that consists of 6 rectangles.  4 of the rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 7 units and a height of 8 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 8 units. The third rectangle has a base of 7 units and a height of 8 units.  The fourth rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 8 units. There is a rectangle connected to the top and a rectangle connected to the bottom of the second rectangle, each with a base of 4 units and a height of 7 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the leftmost rectangular face of the net.  $\blueE{\text{Leftmost rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height} \\\\ &= 7\times 8 \\\\ &= \blueE{56} \end{align}$  The rightmost face has the same area as the leftmost face.  So, we add $\blueE{56}$ twice.

Next, let's find the area of each of the other faces.  The $\goldE{\text{bottom rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height} \\\\ &= 4\times 8 \\\\ &= \goldE{32} \end{align}$  The top face has the same area as the bottom face. So we add $\goldE{32}$ twice.  The $\maroonD{\text{front rectangular}}$ face:  $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{base}\times\text{height} \\\\ &= 4\times 7 \\\\ &= \maroonD{28} \end{align}$  The back face has the same area as the front face. So we add $\maroonD{28}$ twice.

Finally, we add the area of all $6$ faces.  $\blueE{56}+\blueE{56}+\goldE{32}+\goldE{32}+\maroonD{28}+\maroonD{28}$  The following expression represents the surface area of the rectangular prism.  $2\cdot \blueE{56}+2 \cdot \goldE{32}+2 \cdot \maroonD{28}$

question.content: The following figure shows a square-based pyramid.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the pyramid?**

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 10 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 8 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the square pyramid.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.

images.alt: Square pyramid net

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the square base.  $\maroonD{\text{Square}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  10\times10 \\\\ &= \maroonD{100}\end{align}$

Next, let's find the area of each of the triangular faces.  >$\begin{align} \blueD{\text{Area of a triangle}} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 10 \cdot 8\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 80 \\\\ &= \blueD{40} \\\\ \end{align}$  Four of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height. The total area of these four triangles is $\blueD{40}+\blueD{40}+\blueD{40}+\blueD{40}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the rectangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\maroonD{100}+\blueD{40}+\blueD{40}+\blueD{40}+\blueD{40}$

question.content: The following figure shows a square-based pyramid.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the pyramid?**

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 6 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 5 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the square pyramid.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.

images.alt: Square pyramid net

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the square base.  $\maroonD{\text{Square}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  6\times6 \\\\ &= \maroonD{36}\end{align}$

Next, let's find the area of each of the triangular faces.  >$\begin{align} \blueD{\text{Area of a triangle}} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 6 \cdot 5\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot  30\\\\ &= \blueD{15} \\\\ \end{align}$  Four of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height. The total area of these four triangles is $\blueD{15}+\blueD{15}+\blueD{15}+\blueD{15}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the rectangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\maroonD{36}+\blueD{15}+\blueD{15}+\blueD{15}+\blueD{15}$

Next, let's find the area of each of the triangular faces.  >$\begin{align} \blueD{\text{Area of a triangle}} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 4 \cdot 3\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot  12\\\\ &= \blueD6 \\\\ \end{align}$  Four of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height. The total area of these four triangles is $\blueD{6}+\blueD{6}+\blueD{6}+\blueD{6}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the rectangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\maroonD{16}+\blueD{6}+\blueD{6}+\blueD{6}+\blueD{6}$

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 2 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 3 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the square pyramid.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of a square and 4 isosceles triangles. The square has a base of 2 units and a height of 2 units. Each triangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the square base.  $\maroonD{\text{Square}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  2\times2 \\\\ &= \maroonD{4}\end{align}$

Next, let's find the area of each of the triangular faces.  >$\begin{align} \blueD{\text{Area of a triangle}} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 2 \cdot 3\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot  6\\\\ &= \blueD3 \\\\ \end{align}$  Four of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height. The total area of these four triangles is $\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the rectangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\maroonD{4}+\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}+\blueD{3}$

question.content: The following figure shows a square-based pyramid.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the pyramid?**

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 4 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 5 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the square pyramid.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of a square and 4 isosceles triangles. The square has a base of 4 units and a height of 4 units. Each triangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 5 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of the square base.  $\maroonD{\text{Square}}$: $\begin{align} \text{Area} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  4\times4 \\\\ &= \maroonD{16}\end{align}$

Next, let's find the area of each of the triangular faces.  >$\begin{align} \blueD{\text{Area of a triangle}} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 4 \cdot 5\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot  20\\\\ &= \blueD{10} \\\\ \end{align}$  Four of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height. The total area of these four triangles is $\blueD{10}+\blueD{10}+\blueD{10}+\blueD{10}$
Finally, we add the area of all $5$ faces.  The surface area of the rectangular prism can be found with the following expression:  $\maroonD{16}+\blueD{10}+\blueD{10}+\blueD{10}+\blueD{10}$

question.content: The following figure shows a cube.    **Which expression represents the surface area of the cube?**

images.alt: A cube. The height is 5 units.

hints.content: **Surface area** is a 2D measurement. It tells us the number of *square units* it would take to cover the faces of the  3D figure.   [[☃ explanation 1]]  To find the surface area, we need to add the area of each face on the cube.
We can look at a net of the shape to find the area of each face.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 6 squares. All of the squares have side lengths of 5 units. 4 of the squares are are in a row. There is a square connected to the top and a square connected to the bottom of the second square, each with side lengths of 5 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of each face.  $\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  5\times 5 \\\\ &= 25 \end{align}$
There are six square faces with an area of $25$ square units each.   The following expression represents the surface area of the cube.  $25+25+25+25+25+25$

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of each face.  $\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  9\times 9 \\\\ &= 81 \end{align}$

images.alt: A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 6 squares. All of the squares have side lengths of 7 units. 4 of the squares are are in a row. There is a square connected to the top and a square connected to the bottom of the second square, each with side lengths of 7 units.

hints.content: Let's start by finding the area of each face.  $\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &= \text{side}\times\text{side}  \\\\  &=  7\times 7 \\\\ &= 49 \end{align}$
There are six square faces with an area of $49$ square units each. The following expression represents the surface area of the cube.  $6\cdot 49$
